trans-unit.source: Signing a Driver During Development and Testing
trans-unit.target: Signing a Driver During Development and Testing

trans-unit.source: Before you install a driver on a computer running a 64-bit version of Windows, you must sign the driver package.
trans-unit.target: Before you install a driver on a computer running a 64-bit version of Windows, you must sign the driver package.

trans-unit.source: For testing purposes, you can test sign the driver package, which is a more relaxed form of signing than signing for public release.
trans-unit.target: For testing purposes, you can test sign the driver package, which is a more relaxed form of signing than signing for public release.

trans-unit.source: In Microsoft Visual Studio, test signing is enabled by default.
trans-unit.target: In Microsoft Visual Studio, test signing is enabled by default.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you have created a KMDF driver solution as described in [Writing a KMDF driver based on a template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).
trans-unit.target: Suppose you have created a KMDF driver solution as described in [Writing a KMDF driver based on a template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).

trans-unit.source: When you build the solution, you can see in the **Output** window that the driver package has been test signed.
trans-unit.target: When you build the solution, you can see in the **Output** window that the driver package has been test signed.

trans-unit.source: Screen shot of the Output window](images/SigningADriver01.png) Enabling test signing manually
trans-unit.target: Screen shot of the Output window](images/SigningADriver01.png) Enabling test signing manually

trans-unit.source: To manually enable test signing, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To manually enable test signing, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, open a solution that has a driver package project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, open a solution that has a driver package project.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the driver package project, and choose **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the driver package project, and choose **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuation Properties > Driver Signing > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuation Properties > Driver Signing > General**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Sign Mode** drop-down list, select **Test Sign**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Sign Mode** drop-down list, select **Test Sign**.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuation Properties > Inf2Cat > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuation Properties > Inf2Cat > General**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Run Inf2Cat** drop-down list, select **Yes**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Run Inf2Cat** drop-down list, select **Yes**.

trans-unit.source: Viewing the signed driver package
trans-unit.target: Viewing the signed driver package

trans-unit.source: After you build your solution, navigate in File Explorer to the folder that contains your driver package.
trans-unit.target: After you build your solution, navigate in File Explorer to the folder that contains your driver package.

trans-unit.source: One of the files in the package is a catalog file.
trans-unit.target: One of the files in the package is a catalog file.

trans-unit.source: The catalog file contains the digital signature for the package.
trans-unit.target: The catalog file contains the digital signature for the package.

trans-unit.source: For an example of viewing the files in a signed package, see [Writing a KMDF driver based on a template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).
trans-unit.target: For an example of viewing the files in a signed package, see [Writing a KMDF driver based on a template](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/Library/Windows/Hardware/Hh439654).

trans-unit.source: Sharing a signing certificate
trans-unit.target: Sharing a signing certificate

trans-unit.source: When you test sign a driver package, Visual Studio creates a signing certificate (PFX file) and imports it into a certificate store on your host computer.
trans-unit.target: When you test sign a driver package, Visual Studio creates a signing certificate (PFX file) and imports it into a certificate store on your host computer.

trans-unit.source: When you deploy your test-signed driver package to a test computer, Visual Studio copies a verification certificate (CER file) to the test computer.
trans-unit.target: When you deploy your test-signed driver package to a test computer, Visual Studio copies a verification certificate (CER file) to the test computer.

trans-unit.source: If you want to share the certificate with developers who are building drivers on other host computers, you must share the signing certificate, not the verification certificate.
trans-unit.target: If you want to share the certificate with developers who are building drivers on other host computers, you must share the signing certificate, not the verification certificate.

trans-unit.source: To share the signing certificate, follow these steps.
trans-unit.target: To share the signing certificate, follow these steps.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, in the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver package project, and choose **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, in the Solution Explorer window, right-click your driver package project, and choose **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuation Properties > Driver Signing > General**.
trans-unit.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to **Configuation Properties > Driver Signing > General**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Test Certificate** field, choose **Select From Store**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Test Certificate** field, choose **Select From Store**.

trans-unit.source: In the Select Certificate dialog box, locate your test-signing certificate.
trans-unit.target: In the Select Certificate dialog box, locate your test-signing certificate.

trans-unit.source: The name of the certificate will be similar to WDKTestCert *yourName*.
trans-unit.target: The name of the certificate will be similar to WDKTestCert *yourName*.

trans-unit.source: Select your test-signing certificate, and click **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Select your test-signing certificate, and click **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Details** tab, click **Copy to File**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Details** tab, click **Copy to File**.

trans-unit.source: Follow the instructions in the Certificate Export Wizard to export a PFX file.
trans-unit.target: Follow the instructions in the Certificate Export Wizard to export a PFX file.

trans-unit.source: When you are asked whether you want to export the private key, select **Yes, export the private key**.
trans-unit.target: When you are asked whether you want to export the private key, select **Yes, export the private key**.

trans-unit.source: Share the exported PFX file with the other developers.
trans-unit.target: Share the exported PFX file with the other developers.

trans-unit.target: Related topics
